text: Love their soup! Everyone is super nice. Thanks for having wonderful service and great food.

name: Flying Elephants at PDX
attributes: {'RestaurantsTakeOut': 'True', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'", 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'BikeParking': 'False', 'OutdoorSeating': 'False', 'Ambience': "{'romantic': False, 'intimate': False, 'touristy': False, 'hipster': False, 'divey': False, 'classy': False, 'trendy': False, 'upscale': False, 'casual': True}", 'Caters': 'True', 'RestaurantsReservations': 'False', 'RestaurantsDelivery': 'False', 'HasTV': 'False', 'RestaurantsGoodForGroups': 'False', 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'NoiseLevel': "u'average'", 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsPriceRange2': '2', 'WiFi': "u'free'", 'BusinessParking': "{'garage': True, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}", 'Alcohol': "u'beer_and_wine'", 'GoodForMeal': "{'dessert': False, 'latenight': False, 'lunch': True, 'dinner': False, 'brunch': False, 'breakfast': True}"}
categories: Salad, Soup, Sandwiches, Delis, Restaurants, Cafes, Vegetarian
text:
This place is awesome. Really glad I read the reviews and picked here over anything else in the airport! I walked up to the counter and was helped immediately by a guy who looked like the owner. Ordered the $5 pulled pork sandwich and was doubting my decision when a small hoagie roll was brought out. But my sandwich was LOADED! I had to eat it with a fork because there was so much on it.

If you're at PDX, this is the place to go. It's located right outside the baggage claim and security next to Nike. It's rare to find cheap good food at an airport. Sorry Subway, this is a real $5 sandwich.

name: Flying Elephants at PDX
attributes: {'RestaurantsTakeOut': 'True', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'", 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'BikeParking': 'False', 'OutdoorSeating': 'False', 'Ambience': "{'romantic': False, 'intimate': False, 'touristy': False, 'hipster': False, 'divey': False, 'classy': False, 'trendy': False, 'upscale': False, 'casual': True}", 'Caters': 'True', 'RestaurantsReservations': 'False', 'RestaurantsDelivery': 'False', 'HasTV': 'False', 'RestaurantsGoodForGroups': 'False', 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'NoiseLevel': "u'average'", 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsPriceRange2': '2', 'WiFi': "u'free'", 'BusinessParking': "{'garage': True, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}", 'Alcohol': "u'beer_and_wine'", 'GoodForMeal': "{'dessert': False, 'latenight': False, 'lunch': True, 'dinner': False, 'brunch': False, 'breakfast': True}"}
categories: Salad, Soup, Sandwiches, Delis, Restaurants, Cafes, Vegetarian
text: When visiting Portland, I eat at Flying Elephants as often as I can. Amazing soups, especially Mama Leones. Couple that with the ham and cheese sandwich or kale salad and I couldn't be happier. Having a location at the airport means I don't have to wait and I always leave with some. Love it!

name: Flying Elephants at PDX
attributes: {'RestaurantsTakeOut': 'True', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'", 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'BikeParking': 'False', 'OutdoorSeating': 'False', 'Ambience': "{'romantic': False, 'intimate': False, 'touristy': False, 'hipster': False, 'divey': False, 'classy': False, 'trendy': False, 'upscale': False, 'casual': True}", 'Caters': 'True', 'RestaurantsReservations': 'False', 'RestaurantsDelivery': 'False', 'HasTV': 'False', 'RestaurantsGoodForGroups': 'False', 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'NoiseLevel': "u'average'", 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsPriceRange2': '2', 'WiFi': "u'free'", 'BusinessParking': "{'garage': True, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}", 'Alcohol': "u'beer_and_wine'", 'GoodForMeal': "{'dessert': False, 'latenight': False, 'lunch': True, 'dinner': False, 'brunch': False, 'breakfast': True}"}
categories: Salad, Soup, Sandwiches, Delis, Restaurants, Cafes, Vegetarian
text:
Seriously, just go here!  Then you'll never need to read any review as everything will make sense.

I always used to go to Stanford's first, or walk through the security checkpoint and then try my food options. Now, I'll have to head this way instead to stock up on everything I need before my flight.

I eat like every 2 to 3 hours, so I'm able to order something here to sit down and eat quickly before my flight, then pack a few more things to eat on the flight.

Prices are so cheap!  It's like you're not even at the airport.  Drinks actually cost what drinks should cost.  That's right, water isn't $3.   I like to get some mac and cheese or another entree, then order a sandwich and pack it.  There are several sandwich options, all about $4 to $6, and they're not the typical airport sandwiches that one may be wary of. I got an entree, sandwich, and drink all for about $10.

There are lots of cookies, desserts, fruit, salads, and pasta to try too.  I wanted to order 1 of everything, but most of my flights are only about 2 hours.  Plus, if I ate all of that, I'd probably have to upgrade my seat to "even more space" to accommodate an expanding waistline.

I just feel like I'm not really at the airport when I'm here.

name: Flying Elephants at PDX
attributes: {'RestaurantsTakeOut': 'True', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'", 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'BikeParking': 'False', 'OutdoorSeating': 'False', 'Ambience': "{'romantic': False, 'intimate': False, 'touristy': False, 'hipster': False, 'divey': False, 'classy': False, 'trendy': False, 'upscale': False, 'casual': True}", 'Caters': 'True', 'RestaurantsReservations': 'False', 'RestaurantsDelivery': 'False', 'HasTV': 'False', 'RestaurantsGoodForGroups': 'False', 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'NoiseLevel': "u'average'", 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsPriceRange2': '2', 'WiFi': "u'free'", 'BusinessParking': "{'garage': True, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}", 'Alcohol': "u'beer_and_wine'", 'GoodForMeal': "{'dessert': False, 'latenight': False, 'lunch': True, 'dinner': False, 'brunch': False, 'breakfast': True}"}

text:
Barbara, Samantha and Maggie are the number 1, 2 and 3 reasons to visit the Elephant....oh and the great, fresh, local food featured here also! 

These three are friendly, quick with a smile, and free with kind words/comments to all that cross their paths. Rarely have I seen individuals enjoy each others company and their work like these women so apparently do. You must come to the Elephant to see them for yourself......oh and of course to eat! Try the chicken enchiladas special. They are delicious!

text: Best food in the airport(I know thats not usually saying much, but its seriously good stuff). Plenty of options and delicious fresh soup.

name: Flying Elephants at PDX
attributes: {'RestaurantsTakeOut': 'True', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'", 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'BikeParking': 'False', 'OutdoorSeating': 'False', 'Ambience': "{'romantic': False, 'intimate': False, 'touristy': False, 'hipster': False, 'divey': False, 'classy': False, 'trendy': False, 'upscale': False, 'casual': True}", 'Caters': 'True', 'RestaurantsReservations': 'False', 'RestaurantsDelivery': 'False', 'HasTV': 'False', 'RestaurantsGoodForGroups': 'False', 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'NoiseLevel': "u'average'", 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsPriceRange2': '2', 'WiFi': "u'free'", 'BusinessParking': "{'garage': True, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}", 'Alcohol': "u'beer_and_wine'", 'GoodForMeal': "{'dessert': False, 'latenight': False, 'lunch': True, 'dinner': False, 'brunch': False, 'breakfast': True}"}
categories: Salad, Soup, Sandwiches, Delis, Restaurants, Cafes, Vegetarian
text:
Yum!!! Local, delicious grub that isn't overpriced at the PDX airport! There are so many choices here that it's hard to pick what you want. I'd suggest getting something to take with you on the plane, but make sure you're not overwhelmed by your carry-on. (Sometimes passengers can get away with way too much baggage.) 

I'd suggest grabbing a sandwich or a pastry and a coffee beverage. Just make sure you get a drink you can finish before you get to the security checkpoint. I hate it when I overshoot and have to throw out perfectly good coffee because the line went quicker than I thought! (If only the lines were always short!) 

Stop in. I'm sure you can spare a minute for a tasty treat.

name: Flying Elephants at PDX
attributes: {'RestaurantsTakeOut': 'True', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'", 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'BikeParking': 'False', 'OutdoorSeating': 'False', 'Ambience': "{'romantic': False, 'intimate': False, 'touristy': False, 'hipster': False, 'divey': False, 'classy': False, 'trendy': False, 'upscale': False, 'casual': True}", 'Caters': 'True', 'RestaurantsReservations': 'False', 'RestaurantsDelivery': 'False', 'HasTV': 'False', 'RestaurantsGoodForGroups': 'False', 'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'NoiseLevel': "u'average'", 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsPriceRange2': '2', 'WiFi': "u'free'", 'BusinessParking': "{'garage': True, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}", 'Alcohol': "u'beer_and_wine'", 'GoodForMeal': "{'dessert': False, 'latenight': False, 'lunch': True, 'dinner': False, 'brunch': False, 'breakfast': True}"}

text: I came here because I was traveling and I was hungry. I seen they were super busy so I thought to myself I'll try them out. Such a bad idea. Later that day I was throwing up like crazy and I couldn't eat. I went there on Saturday and today is Monday. I'm still feeling sick. I can't eat anything. My stomach feels like its pulsating and I'm still throwing up and have diarrhea. Sorry but I'd never go here again. I got food poisoning.

name: The Reclaimory
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'RestaurantsPriceRange2': '2', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'BikeParking': 'False', 'BusinessParking': "{'garage': False, 'street': True, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}"}
categories: Antiques, Fashion, Used, Vintage & Consignment, Shopping, Furniture Stores, Home & Garden
text: Quaint little store with tons of amazing items! We purchased a cabinet from them and it looks amazing in our house. They are very helpful and always adding new inventory. If you let them know you are looking for a certain item, they will FB message you when they have new stock coming it! I like that customer attention! Makes me a BIG fan of this store. Can't wait to find my next piece.

name: The Reclaimory
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'RestaurantsPriceRange2': '2', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'BikeParking': 'False', 'BusinessParking': "{'garage': False, 'street': True, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}"}
categories: Antiques, Fashion, Used, Vintage & Consignment, Shopping, Furniture Stores, Home & Garden
text:
Gasp! AMAZING!
They took the idea of restoring and modifying vintage furniture and did it flawlessly!
There are other places in town that have tried this and dropped the ball, but not here!

The craziest part is, the prices aren't nearly as high as they should be!!!
Consider how good this stuff looks, the time that went into doing it, the item itself, you're getting a steal of a deal on every item in here!

Now for the things in here, when I showed up I saw:
1 couch
3 chairs 
1 crazy ottoman 
A desk
A bunch of sweet wall art
Turquoise jewelry (necklace, rings, cuffs)
Art

There are 3 vintage furniture stores in a row on this block. If the other two are the meat and cheese, this one would be the tangy mustard you put on your favorite sandwich.

name: The Reclaimory
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'RestaurantsPriceRange2': '2', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'BikeParking': 'False', 'BusinessParking': "{'garage': False, 'street': True, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}"}

text: You know that shop that doesn't have alot but what it does have is truly lovely. Well this is that place. The selection is incredibly sparse but what is there is excellent.

name: The Reclaimory
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'RestaurantsPriceRange2': '2', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'BikeParking': 'False', 'BusinessParking': "{'garage': False, 'street': True, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}"}
categories: Antiques, Fashion, Used, Vintage & Consignment, Shopping, Furniture Stores, Home & Garden
text: I brought in a client and found several pieces for her home. Impeccable restoration and priced well, this store is an absolute gem!

name: The Reclaimory
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'RestaurantsPriceRange2': '2', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'BikeParking': 'False', 'BusinessParking': "{'garage': False, 'street': True, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}"}
categories: Antiques, Fashion, Used, Vintage & Consignment, Shopping, Furniture Stores, Home & Garden
text: just bought a piece of furniture here. I love the selection of mid century they have and the way they restore pieces is truly amazing. so glad I happened upon this place. will be returning shortly.

name: The Reclaimory
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'RestaurantsPriceRange2': '2', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'BikeParking': 'False', 'BusinessParking': "{'garage': False, 'street': True, 'validated': False, 'lot': False, 'valet': False}"}
categories: Antiques, Fashion, Used, Vintage & Consignment, Shopping, Furniture Stores, Home & Garden
text:
The store is small, but the inventory is mighty.

If mid-century design is your jam, then The Reclaimory is your spot. The store is very well curated and the pieces are all in great condition, some restored pieces and some original. They also have a small collection of local art and crafted goods.

You may suffer a bit of sticker shock when you go to pay for an item, but not because the items are expensive but rather because the items are very reasonably priced.

There are a lot of vintage furniture shops in Portland, including a couple shops on this block of Hawthorne, but The Reclaimory has moved its way to the very top of my list.

name: Jasmine Nail Spa
attributes: {'RestaurantsPriceRange2': '1', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False'}
categories: Nail Salons, Beauty & Spas
text: This place is run by a husband and wife. They do a great job and I don't go anywhere else for a brow wax! They do the best they can for just the two of them and squeeze you in when possible. They even work 6 days a week for customers!

name: Jasmine Nail Spa
attributes: {'RestaurantsPriceRange2': '1', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False'}
categories: Nail Salons, Beauty & Spas
text: I got my eyebrows waxed here and she waxed off half my eyebrow. Then proceeded to give up on that one and waxed the other too thin. It took me months to grow my eyebrows somewhat back. They used to be beautiful, now they are ugly and small. I decided to try threading. It's amazing and doesn't leave patches. I don't recommend this place for eyebrow waxing. Bollywood Eyebrows in Tigard Oregon is AMAZING!!!

name: Jasmine Nail Spa
attributes: {'RestaurantsPriceRange2': '1', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False'}
categories: Nail Salons, Beauty & Spas
text: Nice enough people but my don't look good at all, i get shellac done cause it looks nicer and I have my hands in water all day. But the person that did my nails was maybe in a big hurry? Cause they were not cured all the way and as I got in my car the Polish started rubbing off... sorry but I won't go back.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
Worth a visit just for  the unparalleled view of Portland!
$10/adult, you can do a self guided tour or have a guide. We didn't have much time so we went self-guided, the tidbits I overheard from a guide wee very interesting and added to the experience so I suggest doing a guided tour. 
Be sure to stop by the rose garden near here as well.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
One of the best views of Portland! 

Admission into the Mansion is $10 a person, but you can still visit the grounds and see the magnificent view! Parking is free, and it's a very quick drive from downtown to the top of the hill.

If you're short on time or cash, you can skip the tour of the mansion. For the most part it's just furnished rooms from the residents that previously lived there. You can get through it in probably 20 minutes or so.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
Beautiful and interesting museum.

This was a historical gem that I visited since I was a child. Came again to revisit on my vacation. Being on a hilltop, the entire city was fantastic. Although it was windy and cold.

Entrance was about $10 per adult. You get a tour if there are volunteers. I suggest you pay to see the inside. I was still impressed with the home itself. You can tour the groundskeeper home and walk around the mansion. it is totally worth seeing if you visit Portland.

Get there early. Parking may be a gamble.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: This was a fun self guided tour of the mansion built by one of Portland's founding families. The grounds hosted stunning views of the tree line and the city with several walking paths to wonder thru. The inside was well cared for and curated to show a traditional upper class home for the time. Wonderful furnishings and fixtures were set up with great informative and descriptive signs to enjoy. Most of the home is furnished in a way to reflect opulence and wealth but not really how the original family lived there. Most furnishings were far more glam than the pictures of the original rooms which is explained in several areas but I would have liked to see more of the original items or replications of them at least. A great way to spend the morning and an even better way to get amazing pictures of the city and views.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
Favorite stop so far on our magical self-made tour of Portland!
Beautiful mansion and grounds, even on a gloriously foggy Portland day, it was an awesome adventure. 
The rooms are beautiful, and the information provided throughout the house was very interesting. 
Guy was an awesome wealth of information and we had a blast wandering the house asking questions and marveling in the craftsmanship of the artisans who did such intricate plaster, wood, and marble work throughout the house. Well worth the $10 admission to see a house like this continue to hold a piece of history here.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
Pittock Mansion...oh your garden...oh your views...oh the drive up. So beautiful! 

We purchased a Groupon to see this immensely beautiful historic mansion and it was worth it. We spent at least 40 minutes just sitting outside in the garden area taking in the beautiful views Portland has to offer and taking pictures so that we could remember them later. 

I've been to many historical mansions in my day but none has been filled with so many restored rooms as this one! The only room that really creeped me out was the kiddies room. It has all these old dolls just perfectly lined up and looking at you. Jesus, it reminded me of Amityville Horror or something. The other portion I did not care for was the basement art room. Though, it did include excerpts on how the mansion came to be and how it was restored after the residents of Portland put together enough money to buy the house. 

I would have given anything to have lived in this house. Apart from the fact that it gave you a sense of peace and comfort, I just can't get over the freaking views!!!

name: Pittock Mansion

text:
What a beautiful home and the mix of modern and vintage...unique to see a home that was modern in its time.  The grounds are beautiful and the views are breath taking! Glad I came at this time where there was no guided tours, so we were free to roam
The rooms at our own pace.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
This is a fabulous estate located on a large hill in Portland.  In the spring there are many beautiful flowers and flowering trees on the property and gorgeous views of the east mountains.  We went in the spring on a clear day and could see for miles from the lookout points.  
Inside the mansion are many exquisite rooms with period decor.  The building itself is as if from one of my dreams...in excellent condition and well maintained.
This is a great lunch spot or late morning stroll...

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
During January, Pittock is closed for regular maintenance but the grounds is still opened. I hiked from the Pearl district up to the mansion using this route: http://library.oregonmetro.gov/files/pearldistrict_topittock.pdf

It was a fun and challenging hike as it was uphill all the way. It was well worth it as Pittock is in a very quaint neighborhood with beautiful homes. The grounds on Pittock were well kept and reminded me of a manor in Jane Austin times. It also has great views of the city but missed out on the mountain ranges with all the cloudiness. There's also lots of open green spaces and I can imagine what a beautiful picnic spot it would be in warmer sunnier weather.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
Interesting history and great layout and signage for a self-guided tour. This mansion is a Portland gem. The view is pretty darn great as well on a clear day. 

This place is a must for any near Portland residents, or if you have family/friends visiting from out of town. Parking lot is free but lot is small, so I imagine you'll have to walk up on a busy weekend, but there was plenty of spots on a chilly spring weekday.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: Beautiful views of the city from this historic hilltop mansion built in 1914. You can pay $10 for adults ($9 for veterans and seniors) and tour the mansion inside and out, or you can walk around the outside grounds for free and take in the views and shrubbery. Plenty of free parking at the Pittock Mansion Hillside lot. Very large and picturesque mansion, take a look at the pics and see for yourself. On a clear day you can see to Mount Hood and beyond!

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
Pittock Mansion is immaculate! Something that the building developers of today could never replicate or come close to matching up with; the quite modern day features of this house were probably a big deal to them back in the early 1900's when it was built; things like massive walk in closets, refrigerators, etc. were pretty genius for back then.

If for some reason the mansion does not impress you, I sure hope the drive to get there does. The segment of Washington Park extending up towards the house was amazing. Looking straight up and down, the amount of trees and lush greenery. Definitely breathtaking. The views when you get up to the mansion are even better. You can see all of Portland from just about anywhere on the property. 

Where the parking lot is now used to be the old tennis courts of the home. Even the chauffeur's house is extremely nice! Inside the house, everywhere you look there is marble and mahogany, something that costs a pretty penny today, let alone back then. 4,000 square feet on every floor totaling up to 16,000 square feet all together; The Oregonian and other modes of business definitely paid off for Henry Pittock. 

The price is extremely inexpensive to get in and at any age this property can be appreciated. If I ever get a mass amount of money one day, I'd love to purchase this house and live in it for myself.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: The Pittock Mansion has the best views of Portland and all of the surrounding mountains.  On a nice day it's great to start at the mansion's parking lot and hike around Forest Park on the Wildwood Trail.  If you go inside, I highly recommend taking a guided tour.  Check in with the admissions desk to find out when the next one is and walk around the grounds if you need to kill some time.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
Wow, what a view from their back yard!  The grounds are free to wander but there is a fee to tour the mansion.  Pay the inexpensive fee to take the tour if you haven't already.  We opted to do our own self-guided tour as they give you a map and each room as a sign with information on the room that is very informative (the last guided tour of the day looked like it would be crowded which is why we went on our own).  

The grounds may be large but it didn't seem like there was much you could actually walk around through due to all the trees and steep drop - but that view was spectacular!  You can see all of downtown Portland and Mount Hood in the distance.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}

text:
Beautiful place to visit.  You can stop by and enjoy the grounds for free, but if you want to tour the home it will cost a little bit.  Note:  you have to purchase your tickets before you get to the house.  

The house itself is surprisingly small inside.  Doesn't take long to check out the different floors.  It's well kept and the views are gorgeous.  Worth it for the nominal fee to get in.

text:
Pittock Mansion was a cool museum. One you'd imagine your grandmother designed. 

It's not overly large, nor is it really worth the price of admission, but I was some views and to take a break from my hike. Some interesting stuff around the site and estate. You don't really need to pay to check out the views in the back. 

Overall it was a nice way to kill some time.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
Definitely worth checking out if you're visiting the Portland area. My partner and I both love architecture and property, so we might have a greater penchant for this sort of thing, but the views of Portland are definitely worth the stop.

The mansion was lovely, and I appreciate how they provided insights to the interior of the walls, and saved original flooring, and other tidbits like that. We hopped onto a tour, our knowledgable and fun guide was great. Mr. Pittock must have been quite a character, and I'm grateful I got to learn about him and the history of his family. 

I'd love to go back around Christmas and see how they decorate the mansion for the season.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
The Pittock Mansion is a really cool look into what life (albeit a privileged one,) was like 100 years ago.  Old man Pittock may have stood knee high to a pygmy but he spared no expense when it came time to build a really nice house for himself and his family.  Kudos to the Pittock Mansion caretakers who have painstakingly restored the entire place authentically.  The information on the placards in each room did a great job of pointing out the most interesting and less obvious aspects of each space.  

I have to take them to task for their holiday decor, though.  We were told that each year they Foundation decorates a different holiday theme.  This year is was Disney (groan!) SO...each room was also adorned with a Disney theme (Snow White, Beauty & the Beast, etc.) It was really tacky and took away from the whole experience.  I understand why they do it (to increase traffic at that time of year--especially families & kids,) but it could have been done tastefully at least.

Thankfully that's only a holiday thing.  In spite of the cheesiness we really enjoyed ourselves here.

Update: I was recently informed by a Mansion board member that 2007's Holiday theme was "Fairy Tales" and not Disney.  It just so happens that many classic fairy tales have been co-opted and retold by Disney, thus the use of Disney props and memorabilia.  I still think the aesthetic appeal of the mansion was ultimately and unfortunately sacrificed--no matter what the theme was.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: This is a fantastic place to learn a little bit about the history of Portland, view some beautifully staged period rooms, and see a fantastic panorama of the City on a clear day. Mind you, the furniture is not all original to the site, but it is all well-placed and appropriate to the space. The place is well-kept and incredibly affordable at $10 for adults and $7 for youth. Compared to other places of similar kind in other metro areas, this is a reasonable price point. Tours are self-guided and engaging for children and adults--my kids (10 and 8) couldn't stop directing me to take photos, haha! We also appreciated some of the more tactile items, like blueprints that you could flip through and stereoscopes that you could switch out with different images. The lower basement floor includes a gallery that shows local artists' work, and it is an example of what I love about Portland in general: pride in their city, support for their artisans. The outside is a great photo op; and the gift shop has some pretty items. I highly recommend it if you are a fan of history like I am.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}

text: I love this place!!! One of the highlights from my Portland trip. DEFINITELY CHECK IT OUT!!! It's peaceful especially when it's not crowded with people. The mansion is pretty, and the view of the city from this place is nice. There are picnic tables by the view so I saw a family go all out with nice table cloth, silverware, glass cups, and yummy food.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: Good for the panorama view of Portland and if you pay a small fee you can get a guided tour about the house on a hill and Portland history.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
Without a doubt, the Pittock Mansion grounds have the most spectacular view of Portland that includes Mt. Hood in the background. Moreover, you can walk around the grounds for free. The only admission fee is for a tour of the inside of the mansion. While you can certainly drive up to the parking lot of the mansion, there is also a beautiful hike from the city that takes you to the top of the grounds in an hour. I started my hike at the entrance of Lower Macleay Park. I walked on the Lower Macleay trail to the Wildwood Trail. As you walk, you will see a Stone House on the right. You need to continue straight and follow the switchbacks to the Upper Macleay Trailhead then follow the signs pointing you to the mansion. It is my favorite hike within the city. However, I wish I did it in warmer weather. As the temperature during the week was below freezing, there were entire parts of the trail that were covered with ice. I was also wearing old running shoes that did not have much grip left. Consequently, I slipped and wiped out three times. During one of those times, the path was downhill so I sat down and slid down because I knew I would wipe out if I tried to walk anyway. On another segment on the hike up, I was struggling and grabbing on to branches to pull myself up. A girl walked by and asked if I was "ok" then immediately wiped out and fell on her rear end. Her companion laughed hysterically at her. He explained that he is "not a bad person" and he only laughed because he had already fallen 5 times and it was only her first time falling. As I made my way up to the mansion, I realized I had already tried my luck a lot. As a result, I decided to take a cab back to the bottom where I parked. The $10 fee was well worth avoiding a potential broken arm if I fell hard. There is also a limited amount of parking at the entrance of Lower Macleay Park. There is street parking nearby but it is a 2 hour limit. Without losing some time to navigate the ice, I definitely could have made the round trip and enjoyed the view in less than 2 hours. Of course, park at the top of Pittock Mansion and do the hike in reverse if you want to take your time to enjoy and cannot get a parking spot at the entrance of Lower Macleay Park.

If you are visiting Portland or hiking in the nearby area and looking for recommendations, feel free to message me through Yelp and I can share my itinerary, which includes my Yelp reviews. The information for an electronic copy can also be found via my Yelp profile.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: We come here for the view whenever we have guests in town.  I went inside for the first time today, and it is lovely.  Certainly worth doing once.  I would advise taking the tour on your own instead of a volunteer guided tour.  There is a lot of information on the room descriptions that wasn't included in the tour guides' descriptions so it's just as easy to go on yourself.  It is a very interesting house with an interesting history.  Definitely worth the trip.  And if old houses aren't your thing, the view is spectacular on a clear day.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
This is the perfect place to learn about one of the prominent family's in Portland from back in the day. 

My friend and I actually started out at the bottom where the Skene's lived, the help of the Pittock family. They had a pretty nice and cozy spot. About 3,000 sq ft if I remember correctly. Very narrow, but cute and just enough space. 

We then made our way up to the mansion, paid our $11 admission fee, and made our way in. Since it's the holidays, they decorated which was a bit much in some areas (Christmas trees in every room). Took away from the artifact. But in some areas, like the library and music room was beautiful. 

 The furniture is not exactly what the family used, however, it's about what it would have looked like with donated items from that era. Some areas throughout the house have original items locked behind glass, which is what I love to see. The house is gorgeous, with the architecture throughout and the history associated is amazing. What a family!

The house also overlooks Portland and you have a perfect view of the mountains on a clear day. We were able to see no problem the day we went.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
Was on my way to a brewery from the Portland Japanese Garden when my Uber driver suggested quickly stopping by the Pittock Mansion to see the Christmas decors. Little did my friend and I know we'd be spending well over an hour on the grounds of the first mansion in Oregon. 

The Pittock Mansion has 9 bedrooms amongst other rooms fully decorated for the holidays, Santa included! The views from the hill are a panorama of the city of Portland. I would recommend going this time of the year to fully indulge in the festive environment.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: What a gem. The views from this place are amazing.  There are a couple of options, you can take a guided tour or explore the place yourself at your own place depending on what you're in the mood for.  There is also a "behind the scenes tour" that seems to run about once per month where you can see the areas of the mansion that are normally closed off to the public.  This is great place to bring kids or out of town guests.  The outdoor area was also dog friendly so bring Fido for a little exercise.  Assuming the weather allows for it, a nice little picnic in the gardens would really compliment the experience.  They did accept credit cards for admission and could add a donation to your total if so desired.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
We visited the Pittock Mansion in November before the holiday season got underway.  The drive up to the mansion is a bit surreal as you're passing through a regular subdivision-type neighborhood, and it seems out-of-place when you're planning to visit an old, historic structure.

The mansion itself is absolutely breathtaking, we visited on an overcast, misty day and it added an ethereal feel that was altogether charming.  The grounds are wonderful and I recommend walking the grounds as well as touring the house itself.  

Inside, you're transported back to another time and the home has been restored so that walking through each room, it is entirely too easy to picture what life must have been like when the home was in its heyday.  The master bathroom contains a shower that is singularly spectacular.  I want one of those in my house!  The grand staircase is also wonderful, and best viewed from the top all the way down to the basement.  

If I ever brought friends to Portland to show them highlights of the city, I'd include Pittock Mansion.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: If you haven't been here and you are currently reading reviews to figure out if you should come, COME check it out!  I highly doubt you will be disappointed.   This house had so many rooms to view,  and every room explained the history of it, that we didn't need a guided tour.  I actually prefer not to take guided tours in fear of having to feel obligated to seem interested if I'm really not lol.. but I'm sure if we did at this place,  it would've been a bonus.  I really wish we were also able to view the very top of the mansion,  however,  it is blocked off because of safety reasons.  Darn. ..

name: Pittock Mansion

text: Beautfiul grounds.  Can view all of Portland down below (this part is free).  Didn't go inside.  Limited time, and long line.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: Such a beautifully restored mansion high above Portland with views of Mount: St. Helens, Hood and Rainier. Outstanding property on a stunning vista high above the Willamette River. Our tour guide was a volunteer named Barbara and she was a true delight, funny and informative. She made our afternoon, we had a great time.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
Consider this a time travelling experience rather than a museum experience--you will learn the most just by wandering around and soaking up the atmosphere. Two floors (and the basement) are open to the public ($10 admission cost) with 23 rooms carefully arranged to show how a wealthy Portland family might have lived. The architecture alone is worth a visit!
If you have stamina for steep hills, I highly recommend walking up from the Pearl District (use these directions: http://www.oregonmetro.gov/sites/default/files/walk_there_portland_pearl_district_to_pittock_mansion.pdf ). Touring some of the wealthier streets of the Alphabet District builds up to the atmosphere of the Pittock Mansion.

If you don't want to spend the $10 admission fee, at least come here to tour the grounds. The historic gatehouse is open for FREE when volunteers are available and give a tantalizing taster of how well done the Mansion itself is.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: I love to hike up here from the Audubon Society area. it's a great little hike and stays cool when it's really hot. Love having a great view on the top!

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
I'm giving this 3 stars for the chill vibe that's here and the view, NOT for paying for actually going into the mansion (that costs around $12, which I don't think is worth it). I came here on Memorial Day evening after the actual mansion had already closed, and it's actually worth the short drive up the hill just to walk around (and it's free, parking is free!)

Pros:
- cute touristy very PORTLAND spot - you can come chill for about 30 minutes, take in the view of Portland (which isn't bad! see pics), walk around the house, take pictures in front of the beautiful mansion, etc.
- Benches and places to sit around the house if you're coming up here for some alone time, journal, pray, people watch, etc.
- REALLY GREAT FLOWERS! - they look beautiful, there's always bees pollinating them, if you need a cute background for headshots, etc. (honestly, there's probably better flowers here than most greenhouses/ arboretums, etc.) Really therapeutic place to feast your eyes and take in some plant views
- super peaceful vibes - people are always chilling, hanging out with friends, walking their dogs here, etc.
- you get to read these plaques about the Pittocks, Portland history, etc. (all for free, because they're outside the mansion)

Cons:
- the gender neutral bathrooms at the entrance of the mansion are NASTY AF. It literally smelled like feces and urine, there was toilet paper all over the floor. I'm not sure what could possibly happen at the Pittock Mansion that would result in this atrocity, but you have been warned.

text:
Beautiful! The view is breathtaking anytime of the year. The mansion itself is full of history if you want to pay the $10 it costs to get in. It's really cool to see! 

Beautiful gardens and the grounds are very well kept. I could walk around this place all day alone or with a friend or on a date and be perfectly content.

text:
Stunning view. 

I can't comment on the interior but I've walked the grounds and enjoyed the terrace view, and that part is all free. The structure itself is a gorgeous period building from the era of Great Houses. Think shades of Pride & Prejudice or Downtown Abbey. There are lovely gardens and the view onto the city is something special. Worth the trip.

Bring your date, have a picknick on the lawn.

text:
I love the view of Portland and the history of the place but have yet to tour the mansion itself. It is one of the great gems that has been saved from Portland's past and has been restored/kept-up very well. 

It is a perfect starting or finishing place for a hike in Forest Park (http://www.yelp.com/biz/forest-park-portland#query:forrest%20park) or just a picnic on the grass.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: I enjoyed our experience at the mansion. It was so beautiful inside and out. First impressions were a little rough as a guy came out to unlock the door to the ticket building at 11am. The website said it opened at 11am however the door stickers said 11:30. An elderly lady asked him "is this where we get the tickets?" And he replied rather rudely in my opinion as well as a few others "yes, that's what the sign says" and pointed to a small sign he just set out which no one saw. I felt bad for the lady and several people commented on how rude that was. We quickly left it in the past and enjoyed the very beautiful grounds. We did the self guided tour and thought there were plenty of very informative information plaques placed throughout to get a very good idea of the times back then and the Pittock family. We very much enjoyed the visit and would recommend it to others. Would have given 5 stars except for the grumpy guy in the ticket booth.

text: The Pittock Mansion was awesome! The plant garden was very pretty and you could see the whole city. The inside was decorated nicely, it was pretty cool.

name: Pittock Mansion

categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
The Pittock Mansion and Museum is a great place to spend an afternoon. As a new Portlander, I found out about it on accident. I drove up the wooded, winding road to the mansion. It was a perfect late-fall day for such a drive, snow was falling everywhere. Although it was overcast, and I was unable to see the famous views- the mansion and grounds were still beautiful.
The museum volunteer tour guide was so sweet and informative. I also recommend hitting the mansion during the holidays, as it is decorated splendidly. This would be a really fun mother-daughter field trip. I can't wait to go back in spring, to see it in a whole new light! 
Highlights for people who love design and architecture are the Tiffany glaze Turkish smoking room, the fascinating curved design of the interior, and the fabulously well planned views from within the home. I also got a kick out of the vintage bathrooms and kitchen technology.

This was one of a few destinations during a second date, which is probably why the fact it was cloudy out didn't bother me (although it didn't really kill off the view, either).  I would love to go back again, during a blue-sky summer day, to really appreciate the view it holds.

text: Amazing! If you need a new place to check out while visiting Portland or even just to take a break and enjoy a good view of the city, this is the place. The mansion and the views from here are breathtaking. I didn't go inside the Mansion but I will next time I am in town. However if you dont want to go inside then dont, it's definitely worth going and taking a look. This is definitely a cute place to take formal pictures or even have a picnic.

text:
This place is mostly for tourists because of the awesome view in the back. I come here every so often to have a picnic, weather permitting.

I've never gone inside to see the actual museum because I'm not particularly interested and honestly do not want to pay $10 :X

If you happen to visit Portland on a clear sunny day, park in the lot (free parking), and walk around to the back. Make sure that you come when the museum is open because they lock up the gate to the parking lot after 9pm, I believe.... leaving you trapped.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
This place is far as heck!  We were walking from downtown Portland to the mansion, and was told it was a bit over 2 miles.  This wasn't so bad, it took about 40 minutes and we got as close as possible on foot before realizing that there really wasn't a pedestrian walkway available to make it to end, and finally the Mansion.  Additionally, the walkway is parallel and at the side of the road, which felt kind of dangerous as there were fast cars, and no other souls on the road walking the trail, but us.  In the end, we had no other choice but to take the bus, and a really nice man actually helped us navigate which stop we needed and also helped us figure out the schedule of when the bus was arriving.  Portland has an amazing public transportation feature in regards to the bus schedules, where you can text and find out when the next bus is due to arrive.  It was such a neat little feature, and I felt as if I were more excited about this than the actual Mansion, ha!  When we finally got there, there was more trekking to do, uphill, and probably .5 miles before you reach the top of the hill where the Mansion sits so prettily.  There's a great view of the city, without question, the vantage point is stunning but, we were so exhausted from the walk that we didn't stay long, and didn't go on any tours or check out the visitor center (I think it was closed by the time we got there anyhow).  Overall, a fair experience, but I wouldn't say a necessary one.  

3.5 stars.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: The view here is superb. On clear days, you will be treated to snow capped peaks of Adams, Hood, Rainier, and St. Helens. The mansion also occupies Wildwood trailhead connecting to Forest Park.  Depending on your taste, you may opt to skip the tour though. It's $8.50 for adults, and given the fresh air and spectacular views of the surroundings, why linger inside of an old house for pay? Instead, get the views and go get something good to eat at a nearby McMennamins.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}

text: As a lover of history and architecture, I was underwhelmed and bored by the Pittock Mansion. If you're visiting Portland I would recommend skipping it altogether. I was far more interested in the story of the last private inhabitants in the 60s. I wish they would've had information on that.

text:
This is such a tremendous example of the wealth that we had and have in this country it was built in the 1900s and it has every modern convenience of the time what i really found fascinating was that one of the ceilings was covered with aluminum foil which was more expensive (at that time in history ,)than gold leaf or silver .it had hot and cold running water it had a refrigerator it has electric lights the telephone all the new stuff this newspaperman put in his American castle and it truly is an American castle and it's worth going there to support The historical society of Portland and keep such places as this to continue to be maintained and restored .it's early is worth saying it's amazing to me the materials on the quality of things that were built along time ago I couldn't imagine this not being kept for posterity sake go check it out
Fun

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
First, the one negative.  Admission is a bit pricey, but they do offer discounts (AAA, others).  The couple before us also had a LivingSocial or Groupon deal, which I'm sure helped a lot.  That said, the price of admission includes a tour with lots of facts not seen on the plaques in each room (or handy for someone not wanting to read all the plaques). Also, I'm sure upkeep of the large estate and grounds is not cheap.

I went to the Mansion on a rainy day, so I can't attest to the views or grounds, but the Mansion inside is beautifully decorated with period pieces (most of the original pieces having been sold off at an estate sale).  The volunteers give great tours, and being in a big group, you don't notice how creepy some of the rooms are to be in alone.  There's 4 floors and exhibits, so plenty to see (there's a room just for a fridge - a whole room!).

As an added bonus, while I was there, I saw Oscar Nunez from the Office! In Portland's Pittock Mansion, of all places.  The other guests didn't look like they watched The Office (we were the youngest in our group, and we're in our 20s), so he wasn't being noticed, but my husband was sure to notice him, track him down, and get a picture with him!

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: Pittock Mansion happens to be one of Portland's few attractions when it comes to landmarks. Built in 1914, the Pittocks ensures their home would be the most innovative at their time. For a low $10, we were able to tour 3 floors of the incredible mansion and grounds. The view from the grounds alone were worth the ticket price (though the grounds are free to tour). The architecture itself is grand, but the little stories inside along with original fixtures and period pieces were a great story. We happened to come during one of the first days that the home was dressed for the holidays, so trees, ornaments, a live pianist, and even Santa was a treat to see. Though I wished some of the original fixtures such as the funky showers were left sans ornaments, you'll still get an idea of what it would have been like to live in Pittock Mansion. You'll likely spend about an hour roaming about while attentive staff offer their knowledge of various parts of the home. You'll definitely want to make this a pit stop along your trip.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: We stopped here on our short Portland trip. Our 16 year old son really didn't want to see it--thought it would be totally boring. But he was a good sport and went anyway. We all loved it! I think my son even took the most pictures. The tour of the house is very interesting.  It's a great peek into how rich people lived 100 years ago. The grounds are amazing. Unfortunately it was cloudy the day we went so we couldn't see the mountains in the distance but we all agreed that it was worth the stop!

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
Portland doesn't strike you as a city that would have an amazing skyline, and well...it actually doesn't compared to other cities, but the small city quaint vibe that you get from being up at the top of Pittock Mansion is kinda cool.

It's an easy Uber/Lyft ride to the top where you can look around the grounds of the Pittock Mansion for free. I didn't bother actually going inside the actual mansion since it was $11 for admission into some old dudes home, although I did see some people going in. Touring the grounds is a relatively quick thing to do, there's some signage that explains the history of the plants in the area which was informative. When I finished, I actually ended up going down via one of the short hiking trails, which I thought was actually one of the nicer parts of being in the area. From there I ended up randomly on a side of a road when I just carpooled back into the city. 

Overall, if you have a car - go here! It's relatively short to tour the grounds, but there's not much to do if you don't go inside. Hiking trails are great but you'll have to find a way to get back to your car or take an Uber/Lyft when you make it back to the end. It's a bit of a hassle compared to other places but when in Portland, you gotta go with the local flow I guess.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
If you're new to Portland or a tourist like me, definitely come check out this place.

The mansion itself and the surrounding grounds are really cool, but the real gem of this place is the backyard view of Downtown Portland and Mt. Hood behind it. The history behind this place if you're a nerd like me is pretty cool. I didn't get a chance to go into the mansion itself, but if you come early enough you should be able to.

Once you're done checking out the mansion, go to the rest of Forest Park! It's pretty amazing that this place is all within the city limits of Portland.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
Now y'all know I love to tour a solid historic home...especially ones that are well kept and historically accurate. Pittock Mansion fits the bill!

It was gorgeous as we arrived so we toured the gardens first and got to watch some teenagers bicker about the perfect selfie angle. The gardens and flours were beautiful as was the sky. Plus that bit is free!

Next we toured the house and I appreciated the attention to detail of the craftsman who built the home, the architects and the historians who put up explanatory placards. Because I am a dork, my favorite rooms were probably the kitchen and the bathrooms. Dang old man Pittock had a FANCEE shower + that foot bath... I might need one of those.

So much fun and the architecture is so different from what I'm used to. Totally worth the $$ and a lovely way to spend an hour or two.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}

text:
Best Portland views in the city! 

We had a Groupon for our tickets, everyone was super nice and we got a guided tour. The gardens are the best part of the house.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
I Couldn't stop staring at all the fabric, rugs, lights...really draws you into a time warp. 
Wanted to learn everything...fascinating! Well, preserved! 

So...Apparently people were royally hosed by being born into a decade without Apple products, dermabrasion, or charter flights...just kidding...seriously,.. It was nice to see that we have better fabric choices and electricity..
HELLO SCARY SPARKS..REALLY!
Mr. Pittock,  My Candle will do...just FINE, just fine, thank you like Mr. Jeffersons...just fine..oh and please do not test that hissing gas light of a contraption oozing dangerously, skin turning, nauseating, explosive, chemical substance in my guest room...Holy candle!.. I would have been the one walking around totally Paranoid, when that Hot Mess was being tested and installed.
"Mr. PITTOCK sir, shouldn't we wait till the next generation of light comes out?...NO thank you!, drop to your knees and thank you mamma! For never having to survive that horrific nightmare, Gas Light! 
But then again...it was Fantastic to see....not much has changed either. At least what was considered affluent then, is basically middle class now. Except the kitchen! Ooh GIRLS... do we rock it now...HEY!!

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}

text: It was very cold when I went up to the mansion, but it was to be expected this time of year. The view was amazing  and there were trails for hiking. Unfortunately, the mansion was closed when I was there. If you love a good view, it's a place to go when in Portland. It's easy to get to, free parking, AND free restrooms (a rare Portland amenity).

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: Went here on a whim when we were in town and were looking for a museum to check out. It was a great find and chock full of interesting history. Very interesting to hear about one of Portland's newspaper magnates. The house is luxurious and more than modern for its time. The docent that took us around was very knowledgeable and I was loving all the little factoids about the history of the mansion, the family, and what they meant to Portland. We didn't have time, but if you do it's worth checking out the trails the lead up to the mansion or even have a picnic on the grounds because that is open to the public. How cool is that!

categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: Extremely disappointed. The mansion was completely ruined with cheap, crappy modern Christmas decor in every nook and cranny to the point you couldn't even get to the cool things that at least looked authentic or period. And it wasn't just the Christmas destruction, the mansion was full of stuff that had little historic value.  For example, the cook was Chinese so there was a crapload of cheap modern Chinese junk. You can't even see, or feel, what the kitchen was like because was so stuffed with, well, junk. And it was truly junk. Things you'd get from a party store. Again, literally destroying any historical significance.  So sad that the architecture and feel of the place was hidden behind all the junk and crap. Complete waste of money. Somewhere in that cheap party store was a beautiful, historical mansion.

text:
This is my favourite view of Portland! When my friend brought me here for the first time was a Friday summer evening with very little folks calmly enjoying the sunset and I this spot became my absolute favourite
This place has about 200 variety of roses, but be careful though the bees might sting you. The mansion is pretty too but I come here mostly for the view ! On clear day you can see the MT hood too !

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}

text:
Great views, beautiful grounds and landscaping. Good restoration done on the home from the outside (didn't take the tour inside). Good workout on the trail into Forest Park too. 
If you are debating between Council Crest Park or Pittock for views of the city this would be my choice hands down.

text:
I didn't have a chance to go inside, but the grounds and the views are a must see while in Portland.

Great place to have an afternoon picnic or an inexpensive date.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
Overall, this is a nice place to visit.  The view from the gardens and walk are exceptional.  However, the price for touring the mansion is pretty steep for what you get.  We did the self-guided tour which was nice and the signs let you know quite a bit about the various rooms.  However, there were certain rooms with no signs so you really didn't get any additional information.

I would knot do a return trip to see the mansion, but I would definitely go back for the views from the exterior.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text: Well worth the trip. The volunteers truly love what they do and take you through the tour telling stories that bring the mansion to life and you can imagine the family there. The surrounding grounds are exceptional, and well-groomed. The gate house below is fun because it's so quirky and kept true to the time the gatekeeper and his family lived there

name: Pittock Mansion

text: Don't go during their Christmas time event, the decorations are not authentic to the period and it ruins the experience. If feels like the Christmas decoration isle at Michael's with some antiques here and there.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
categories: Tours, Museums, Architectural Tours, Venues & Event Spaces, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Hotels & Travel, Arts & Entertainment, Community Service/Non-Profit, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Public Services & Government, Historical Tours
text:
I found out about this place through a Portland Tourism website and immediately knew I wanted to check this place out. Once occupied by Henry Pittock and his family, this compact palace served it's purpose high about Portland.

This was your typical mansion with ornamental accents, modern amenities (for a house of that era) and interesting stories. Much of the original furniture was still intact but alas you could not touch or sit on it. Mostly this is a self-guided tour with volunteers running a guided your every half hour. You also have the option of staying for a behind-the-scenes tour which is $20 as opposed to the general admission of $9.95.

Overall this is great place to visit. If you don't feel like touring the house, you're more than welcome to walk around the gardens surrounding the mansion. Here you get some breathtaking views of Portland proper while also taking in the pristine greenery growing all over the hillside in which the mansion calls home.

I'd love to come back for a garden picnic or to just take in the scenery again. It's a must-see when visiting the Rose City :)

name: Pittock Mansion

text: Great to visit, easy to navigate and there's lot of info about what used to be posted all around the house! Make sure to walk the gardens and check out the outer house further down the property. Not much going on in the gift shop but the peanut butter pretzels were a great easy snack to have while walking the grounds

text:
My friend and I were visiting Portland for the day and were recommended to visit Pittock Mansion. Based on my research, the mansion has a fantastic view. Due to time constraints we couldn't go inside but the exterior was beautiful!

The parking lot doesn't accommodate that many vehicles so carpool or maybe Uber/Lyft?

Would definitely make time to check out this place during my next visit.

text: We didn't actually went inside the house. Just walked the grounds and enjoyed the view. If you have a car while visiting Portland, definitely stopped by. The view is worth it!

name: Pittock Mansion

text: Free.  Another free attraction that is worth the stop.  Beautiful mansion, gorgeous grounds, fragrant flowers in bloom during the season, one of the best views of the Portland skyline you will find around, plenty of parking, and a nice place to make out if you happen to be by yourselves.  I have not been on the tour yet but the mansion is stunning from what little I have seen of the inside.  Definitely a must stop on a boring summers day.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}

text:
One of the most beautiful places in all of Portland! The place really tells the story of Portland, snd the people who framed the great city we enjoy. 

Without a doubt beautiful grounds, and the house is affordable to tour, with both self guided and structured tours.

The view is amazing! 

Truly; Portlands best spot.

name: Pittock Mansion
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': 'True', 'GoodForKids': 'True', 'ByAppointmentOnly': 'False', 'RestaurantsAttire': "u'casual'"}
